there is a proven correlation between depression and nerve pain or neuropathy (burning, tingling, pain, especially in the feet).   Neuropathy is often treated with antidepressants.   ADs are not "one size fits all"..  they have different mechanisms of action (SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, etc.).  Cymbalta and Lyrica are two of the newer meds used for neuropathy; Cymbalta is an SSRI (seratonin reuptake inhibitor).  It is sometimes a trial and error process to find the right one for you.  It is always recommended to rule out other sources of neuropathy.  These include diabetes, nerve impingement (such as thoracic outlet syndrome) , some medications, alcoholism, and a family history of peripheral neuropathy.  good luck,  Lisa

Also, there is a topical cream for neuropathic pain.  Find a compounding pharmacy in your area.  The cream usually includes gabapentin (neurontin).  It is applied topically and depletes something called "p substance", which is a pain mediator.  This can be very helpful and is much better than throwing another drug into the mix.  There is also an over-the-counter cream called Zostrix for nerve pain.  It is made with capsaicin, which is derived from jalapeno peppers, so don't go sticking your fingers in your eyes after applying it!!! hope this helps.
